column2: Victoria Station, still named after the great nineteenth-century Queen, was neither more nor less busy than usual as he came into it half-an-hour later.
column3: Victoria Station, still named after the great nineteenth century Queen, was neither more nor less busy than usual as he came into it half an hour later.

column2: The vast platform, sunk now nearly two hundred feet below the ground level, showed the double crowd of passengers entering and leaving town.
column3: The vast platform, sunk now nearly two hundred feet below the ground level, showed the double crowd of passengers entering and leaving town.

column2: Those on the extreme left, towards whom Percy began to descend in the open glazed lift, were by far the most numerous, and the stream at the lift-entrance made it necessary for him to move slowly.
column3: Those on the extreme left, towards whom Percy began to descend in the open glazed lift, were by far the most numerous, and the stream at the lift entrance made it necessary for him to move slowly.

column2: He arrived at last, walking in the soft light on the noiseless ribbed rubber, and stood by the door of the long car that ran straight through to the Junction.
column3: He arrived at last, walking in the soft light on the noiseless ribbed rubber, and stood by the door of the long car that ran straight through to the Junction.

column2: It was the last of a series of a dozen or more, each of which slid off minute by minute.
column3: It was the last of a series of a dozen or more, each of which slid off minute by minute.

column2: He felt quiet now that he had actually started.
column3: He felt quiet now that he had actually started.

column2: He had made his confession, just in order to make certain of his own soul, though scarcely expecting any definite danger, and sat now, his grey suit and straw hat in no way distinguishing him as a priest (for a general leave was given by the authorities to dress so for any adequate reason).
column3: He had made his confession, just in order to make certain of his own soul, though scarcely expecting any definite danger, and sat now, his grey suit and straw hat in no way distinguishing him as a priest (for a general leave was given by the authorities to dress so for any adequate reason).

column2: He had only the violet thread in his pocket, such as was customary for sick calls.
column3: He had only the violet thread in his pocket, such as was customary for sick calls.

column2: He was sliding along peaceably enough, fixing his eyes on the empty seat opposite, and trying to preserve complete collectedness when the car abruptly stopped.
column3: He was sliding along peaceably enough, fixing his eyes on the empty seat opposite, and trying to preserve complete collectedness when the car abruptly stopped.

column2: He looked out, astonished, and saw by the white enamelled walks twenty feet from the window that they were already in the tunnel.
column3: He looked out, astonished, and saw by the white enamelled walks twenty feet from the window that they were already in the tunnel.

column2: The stoppage might arise from many causes, and he was not greatly excited, nor did it seem that others in the carriage took it very seriously; he could hear, after a moment's silence, the talking recommence beyond the partition.
column3: The stoppage might arise from many causes, and he was not greatly excited, nor did it seem that others in the carriage took it very seriously; he could hear, after a moment's silence, the talking recommence beyond the partition.

column2: Then there came, echoed by the walls, the sound of shouting from far away, mingled with hoots and chords; it grew louder.
column3: Then there came, echoed by the walls, the sound of shouting from far away, mingled with hoots and chords; it grew louder.

column2: The talking in the carriage stopped.
column3: The talking in the carriage stopped.

column2: He heard a window thrown up, and the next instant a car tore past, going back to the station although on the down line.
column3: He heard a window thrown up, and the next instant a car tore past, going back to the station although on the down line.

column2: This must be looked into, thought Percy: something certainly was happening; so he got up and went across the empty compartment to the further window.
column3: This must be looked into, thought Percy: something certainly was happening; so he got up and went across the empty compartment to the further window.

column2: Again came the crying of voices, again the signals, and once more a car whirled past, followed almost immediately by another.
column3: Again came the crying of voices, again the signals, and once more a car whirled past, followed almost immediately by another.

column2: There was a jerk--a smooth movement.
column3: There was a jerk-a smooth movement.

column2: Percy staggered and fell into a seat, as the carriage in which he was seated itself began to move backwards.
column3: Percy staggered and fell into a seat, as the carriage in which he was seated itself began to move backwards.

column2: There was a clamour now in the next compartment, and Percy made his way there through the door, only to find half-a-dozen men with their heads thrust from the windows, who paid absolutely no attention to his inquiries.
column3: There was a clamour now in the next compartment, and Percy made his way there through the door, only to find half a dozen men with their heads thrust from the windows, who paid absolutely no attention to his inquiries.

column2: So he stood there, aware that they knew no more than himself, waiting for an explanation from some one.
column3: So he stood there, aware that they knew no more than himself, waiting for an explanation from some one.

column2: It was disgraceful, he told himself, that any misadventure should so disorganise the line.
column3: It was disgraceful, he told himself, that any misadventure should so disorganise the line.

column2: Twice the car stopped; each time it moved on again after a hoot or two, and at last drew up at the platform whence it had started, although a hundred yards further out.
column3: Twice the car stopped; each time it moved on again after a hoot or two, and at last drew up at the platform whence it had started, although a hundred yards further out.

column2: Ah! there was no doubt that something had happened!
column3: Ah! there was no doubt that something had happened!

column2: The instant he opened the door a great roar met his ears, and as he sprang on to the platform and looked up at the end of the station, he began to understand.
column3: The instant he opened the door a great roar met his ears, and as he sprang on to the platform and looked up at the end of the station, he began to understand.

column2: From right to left of the huge interior, across the platforms, swelling every instant, surged an enormous swaying, roaring crowd.
column3: From right to left of the huge interior, across the platforms, swelling every instant, surged an enormous swaying, roaring crowd.

column2: The flight of steps, twenty yards broad, used only in cases of emergency, resembled a gigantic black cataract nearly two hundred feet in height.
column3: The flight of steps, twenty yards broad, used only in cases of emergency, resembled a gigantic black cataract nearly two hundred feet in height.

column2: Each car as it drew up discharged more and more men and women, who ran like ants towards the assembly of their fellows.
column3: Each car as it drew up discharged more and more men and women, who ran like ants towards the assembly of their fellows.

column2: The noise was indescribable, the shouting of men, the screaming of women, the clang and hoot of the huge machines, and three or four times the brazen cry of a trumpet, as an emergency door was flung open overhead, and a small swirl of crowd poured through it towards the streets beyond.
column3: The noise was indescribable, the shouting of men, the screaming of women, the clang and hoot of the huge machines, and three or four times the brazen cry of a trumpet, as an emergency door was flung open overhead, and a small swirl of crowd poured through it towards the streets beyond.

column2: But after one look Percy looked no more at the people; for there, high up beneath the clock, on the Government signal board, flared out monstrous letters of fire, telling in Esperanto and English, the message for which England had grown sick.
column3: But after one look Percy looked no more at the people; for there, high up beneath the clock, on the Government signal board, flared out monstrous letters of fire, telling in Esperanto and English, the message for which England had grown sick.

column2: He read it a dozen times before he moved, staring, as at a supernatural sight which might denote the triumph of either heaven or hell.
column3: He read it a dozen times before he moved, staring, as at a supernatural sight which might denote the triumph of either heaven or hell.

column2: EASTERN CONVENTION DISPERSED.	EASTERN CONVENTION DISPERSED.
PEACE, NOT WAR.
column3: PEACE, NOT WAR.
